comments.commentBody: There is a difference between self-confidence and arrogance, David. Starting with the President, most of our leaders are too arrogant to see any view or way other than their own.

"I’ve always had a slightly maverick side that actually stood me in great stead."

Luckily for Andrew Cosslett, all is not lost. He can just follow John McCain's model & declare, "I never considered myself a maverick."

I doubt if your "humble hound" model possesses any leadership skills, tho she would be great in high-level management. In fact, there are lots of such people already there. Leadership, as Cosslett boasted, requires self-confidence, empathy, & perception.

But both of your examples provide evidence of what's wrong with Republicans. Both of your models are motivated to change the status quo. Both understand there is always room for improvement. And neither is afraid to try new things; they know the new course might not work perfectly, so they're ready to adapt & make modifications from the get-go. Does that sound like your Republican friends? Nope. They keep promising to return to the days of Ronald Reagan & "Just Say No." Never mind that Reagan's domestic & economic policies were unmitigated disasters that plunged us into 30 years of decline. Republicans want to "beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past."

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

So, Krugman's plan for us to return to "rapid growth" is:

a) cap-and-trade which will "only" cut growth by 25-30% per year per Krugman's article in Sunday NYT?
b) start universal health care with NOTHING done to cut escalating medical costs?
c) say that having 47% of households paying ZERO income tax is just fine?
d) rely on "green jobs", which include solar power, built in Asia, and wind mills, built in China? Huh?

Once you erase the phony, financial bubble, the U.S. economy has been stagnant for 17 years. Where, Mr. Krugman, is the growth going to come from?

The Four Seasons Hotel Sultanahmet is located in the historic Sultanahmet area inside the old city. It is in easy walking distance of the Blue Mosque, Haigia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern and Grand Bazaar, as well as many other Roman and Ottoman ruins which are amazingly preserved. The hotel is less than one year old, it is small and quaint with nicely appointed rooms, very clean, and with wonderfully friendly management and staff.
They arranged an airport transfer for us from the hotel and greated us with enthusiasm at 1 AM when we arrived. I cannot say enough good things about the staff - they made bookings for us, arranged taxis, recommended good restaurants,the hotel were happy to book our tours and hamams which made things so easy for us... and answered all of our many questions with enthusiasm that you don't see in LA.The breakfast was ample although we would have liked more fresh fruit. The dining room was charming and had the remains of ancient palace walls. Tea and cake was served in the late afternoon. The wireless worked well.(NOT FREE)
I would absolutely stay at the FSH Sultanahmet Hotel again. I could not have been more pleased than I was with my stay at this hotel and visit to Istanbul. Excellent in all regards.We would definitely consider coming back to Fourseason the next time we go to Istanbul.

What a ridiculous, obvious, and condescending question. Here's why, NY Times: you have people like my spouse who have master's degrees and 15 years of experience who have been unemployed for almost a year and are lucky if they can land an interview every three months. Never mind an actual job offer.

Without jobs there is no recovery. End of story.

It's simple. We haven't corrected our trade imbalance and are still being propped up by massive government spending. Our manufacturing capacity has been gutted through outsourcing, and at least where I work they're attempting to do the same thing with accounting, research, operations and IT. (Incidentally, importing unskilled workers, training them, and then sending the job overseas isn't helping anyone that I can see.)

So yes, I'm still pessimistic. None of the core problems with our economy or government have been addressed, and the parties in power seem intent on destroying each other rather before they'll take a serious look at anything.

Of course, CNBC and the Wall St. Journal realized that Obama bashing was ultimately not good fore their business, which is to help "money managers" and corporations thrive. This could not happen if they tell it like it really is, and have converted Bernanke's "green shoots" into the "recovery" song.

162,000 NEW jobs were created last month. During the same month, 1.3 million new claims for unemployment were filed. Nevertheless, "we have turned the corner" is the new mantra!
when my kids and friends have meaningful jobs back, I'll believe it.The only people who have "recovered" are the rich.

You just don't get it. Everything is getting worse. We passed health care which means my health care costs are going up along with my taxes. The Bush Tax cuts are going away.People are not stupid they getting ready for the second coming of the storm. Raising taxes on business and individuals is never a good idea and during a recession it should be criminal. Add to that Obama's reckless spencing. He ran on hope and change and all people is fear and anxiety. No there is transformation for you.

the 'recovery' is on wall street and in the banking industry which is controlling our government....it is a statistical recovery which is enjoyed by government workers and the financial industry only....actual people do not feel this at all, and they continue to find jobs that pay $9/hour and then fill up their cars at $3/gallon....recovery....no, not really.......disposable income?? please, do not make me laugh....ekeing out the necessities......maybe.....we hope......recovery....hahaha...unless you are a VP  at goldman sachs or wells fargo and laughing at the great unwashed masses, please do not talk to me about a 'recovery'

What recovery? The majority of the jobs created were govt and temp workers for the census. Again, i ask what recovery? We have people falling off the unemployment rolls and they are not counted. Unless i am in candy land we just received the latest job report and unemployment is rising. Again, i ask what recovery?

I have just read every comment. It is my fondest wish that Americans who feel it is appropriate to comment in the Times, do more. Let us organize and take back our country. There are a lot of incredibly intelligent readers out there who I know would love to be organized behind making the banksters on Wall Street give us our money back. An organization that will pressure our purchased public officials to simply do the right thing. Why should we exist in a plutocratic society where the plutocrats continue to divide this country while sucking this country/world of everything the next generations will surely need.

Someone PLEASE show me an organization/person who is building towards this end. I will gladly join and donate my time. I am unemployed anyway.

Is this the kind of democracy that we want other countries to follow? What a disaster.

Who pays taxes? Anyone who buys anything... very few are rich enough to pay their taxes when they have no income; if they have income, it is coming in from someone else who bought something.

About 35% of every dollar we spend goes to pay somebody else's taxes up the production chain. It is an illusion that the poor don't pay taxes.... they simply pay them indirectly if they buy anything.... and if they are so poor they are "given" everything, they pay their "tax" in the form of future slavery and even deeper poverty.

Only one way out.... honest work, by all of us; and everybody's waiting for someone else to do the work.... or at least, the honest work.

Well, Floyd, maybe we're just too pessimistic, but at 68 I experienced 1975, 1982, etc., and this feels different to me. I can't just shake it off. Maybe, as you seem to suggest, I am wrong, but...

I've been in business for myself since 1966. I'm still doing ok. Not killing anything, but ok. However, I was chary about the economy in 2007 and sold excess stuff, reduced debt, built up cash, etc. I suffered somewhat in 2008 but I'm at leat even now. I have good friends who have been badly hurt. They are not incompetents or dummies. They were just operating like it was another recession.

I don't think so. I think there is a sea change, a secular shift away from debt and mindless consumption. I think there is a baby-boom generation deeply worried about how they are going to finance their retirement. I have children who though reasonably successful still casn't afford housing of the sort they would like.

I see government fumbling about. I like Obama, but notice that he has no connection whatsoever to the part of America that generates wealth, just to the part that is, reasonably, concerned about economic justice, fairness and redistribution. But not understanding how small and medium business prosper could be fatal to his plans.

I'm going to remain hunkered down until the evidence of recovery is overwhelming and even then I am going to be very wary.

Sorry!

I recall that the last big recession (1982) was like this one. Back then I heard for a year and half that the recession was over. No one believed it because for the majority it wasn't true. For the general public the recession is not over until employment substantially picks up - not a few months of a decellerating rate of increasing job losses. All the indicators are interesting (ie. Dow, S&P, consumer sentiment) but the only thing that will end the recession will be employment. I think economists have to rethink the definition of what a recovery is.

by definition once things stop getting worse, they get better because of comparisons - year over year, quarter over quarter, etc.  Better does not necessarily equal good.  Just because things may be less bad for some people does not mean that they are good, or even just getting better, for everyone else.  Where are the jobs going to come from?  Mc-Taco-Mart part time, minimum wage, no benefit jobs?  And you ask why  those >10% unemployed and 20+% underemployed people are not excited and optimistic about their allegedly improved prospects.  Really, that's what you're asking?
I can just see President Obama exclaiming, "Who are you going to believe, me or your lying eyes?"

As Joseph Stiglitz indicates in his book "Freefall" --aggregate demand is not strong enough to ensure full global employment

Our economy is on life support, being kept alive by federal stimulus and other deficit-financed spending.

We must focus on increasing the discretionary purchasing power of the middle class before it is too late.

“This is America’s middle class, we’ve hacked at it and pulled at it and chipped at it for 30 years now, and now there’s no more to do. We fix this problem going forward, or the game really is over.”
Elizabeth Warren on “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart”, 26 Jan 2010

One hopes that we will somehow muddle through but another oil shock, bank failure or major inflation piled on top of where we are now could very well put our very democracy at risk.

What is particularly devastating is that rich industrialists such as Rupert Murdoch and David Koch are financing foment. Don't they realize that industrialists financed both Hitler and Castro with dire consequences. The Teaparty movement doesn't have a leader, but once one emerges, watch out. Eric Hoffer in "The True Believer" wrote that the leader of a movement of those who have lost self-respect need not be rational, but only promise a better life, blame scapegoats and be totally consistent. With TV and radio media, facebook, youtube etc. his power will be greatly magnified.

Our country can only rise again if led by increasing middle class purchasing power.

I think that this is a treaty that all Americans can agree upon. It doesn’t take a genius to know that we simply do not need enough nuclear weapons to destroy the world more than once over. We don’t even need enough weapons to destroy the world once over.
I usually do not go on these liberal rants, but it is about time that we as a country understand that our previous generations made some silly decisions and invested money into areas of destruction rather than progress. Sure, I understand national security is a necessity, but there is a point when it just becomes too much.
I applaud both leaders for putting aside even their recent differences to agree on a matter that will directly affect numerous other countries. This is a step forward, but there is still so much work to be done in the area of nuclear weapons.
I’m sure that the plans of an American nuclear base in Europe will begin some sort of problem again, but at least the levels of nuclear power have been decreased. I can only hope that all citizens can view this as progress. We must avoid nuclear warfare at all costs.

CA is finally coming to its senses after decades of endless spending.  People in SF are finally getting it that the gravy train is over - schools are closing, masses of people are unwillingly unemployed, transit has been cut back - there is simply no money despite our high taxes.  Obama has lost his support base with gays, environmentalists, seniors, etc.

Having seen the unique Jeter gesture a few thousand times myself, I've never understood: Is he really asking the ump to call "time out" every pitch? That would mean the ump also has to call "play" when Jeter drops his arm -- which is preposterous. So it really seems Jeter is calling the time out -- which leads to the "Presumptuous" comment above. Except the poster is in Boston, oc.
A lawyer might say Jeter is just signaling he's not really "in the box" or "settled in the box" until he drops his arm. What's wrong with that?
Anyway, if you are upset abt pace of games, the stepping out is the issue.
Oh wait . . . at least 50% of pitchers aren't ready anyway!

Gee whiz, what nasty NY Times readers! I would expect the caliber of the comments here to a slightly more intelligent.

This is a great program that engages kids and produces a high quality product; what more could you want? This teacher is one of the extremely intelligent and focused hard-working types that any school would be lucky to have.

But, having absolutely no heart, not to mention personal knowledge of the program, won't stop the garbage flowing from judgmental mouths like those of Ajit and luvmtains. You two ought to send the school a check.

Yours truly,
Skyline parent
The falafel was unbelievably yummy! My boyfriend and I took one bite of a sample and were jumping to get a whole pita full. Wow. What a treat. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

Nobody is defending longer games.  I'd be very happy to live in the retro world of Seaver versus Gibson in 90 minutes.  For better or worse, the game has evolved.  Compare the number of complete games pitched in 1970 to the number thrown in 2009.  This isn't about people standing around idly. Let's assume that the average pitching change takes 2 or 3 minutes and multiply it by 3 or 4 changes per team, per game, then it's not a giant leap of understanding to figure out where another half hour or so is coming from.  Add in at least another 20 minutes of commercial time between innings per game since the 70's .  With practically every team in the league building new stadiums and trying to maximize per square foot profit, do you really think owners will complain when they're selling overpriced souvenirs and food for 4 hours instead of 2?  I'm sure even the Royals benefit from keeping the cash registers open that much longer.

Skip Pagliacci.  There are so many better pizza places.  Instead Via Tribunali in Capitol Hill or Queen Anne or try Serious Pie downtown.  For brunch, I have to agree with others - 5 Spot Cafe or Portage Bay Cafe.  You also can't go wrong with Coastal Kitchen or Pesos.  For dinner, my favorite is Betty on Queen Anne hill.  Greasy spoon (but delicious) = Mike's Chili in Ballard.  Late night has to be at Beth's Cafe.  If you're visiting, be sure to try a bowl of Pho and a Vietnamese sandwich.
